content.webTitle: Mystery bird: Abyssinian siskin, Serinus nigriceps | GrrlScientist

fields.headline: Mystery bird: Abyssinian siskin, Serinus nigriceps
fields.bodyText: Adult male Ethiopian black-headed siskin, Serinus nigriceps, also known as the Ethiopian siskin or (African/Abyssinian) black-headed siskin, or the black-headed serin, photographed at Bale Mountains, Ethiopia (Africa). Image: Dan Logen, 1 February 2011 [velociraptorize]. Nikon D300s, 600 mm lens with 1.4 extender, ISO 800, f/8, 1/1250 sec. Question: This lovely African songbird is an Ethiopian endemic -- it is found nowhere else in the world. Can you tell me the name of its taxonomic family? Can you identify the species? Response: This is adult male black-headed siskin, Serinus nigriceps. This Ethiopian endemic is distinct from all other species in the area, so it's not easy to confuse with anything else. It is currently a member of Fringillidae (true finches), although the taxonomy of this family and genus needs a lot of work. You are invited to review all of the daily mystery birds by going to their dedicated graphic index page. If you have bird images, video or mp3 files that you'd like to share with a large and (mostly) appreciative international audience here at The Guardian, feel free to contact me to learn more. . email: grrlscientist@gmail.com twitter: @GrrlScientist
